lines: You are a guest at your friend Missy's house. Her mom gives you both a box of crayons and two pieces of paper.
You are behaving yourself very nicely so far. You draw a pretty picture.
A very strong sign of developing social etiquette. Emily Post would certainly approve.
A very nice gesture. You can have a good time at somebody else's house for a short while, but there's no place like home.
You draw large circles and swirls with black crayon on the paper. Oops!  You drew on the expensive tablecloth.
Missy is a gracious hostess. She excuses you, then adds a stroke or two to your design (on the tablecloth, that is).
You casually slide the paper over the offending spot, where it will remain covered and undetected until after you leave. This was the sneaky, cowardly way out. But it was smart!
Your honesty is commendable. Missy's mom realizes she wasn't thinking clearly when she let you draw on top of the tablecloth. Will you be this honest when you get yourself into real trouble?
Probably not, but admitting this is a trustworthy sign in itself.
You scribble back and forth wildly, creating bold slashes of color. When you are finished, you can:
Ah yes, the frustrated artist. Your impulsiveness combined with your desire for perfection keeps you in a state of "artistic turmoil."
You appreciate the value of even this kind of emotional expression. When you are famous, this scribbling might be worth a fortune.
You and Missy work each other into a frenzy. First you cover the paper, then Missy suggests you redecorate the kitchen.

You and Missy create a fabulous mural on the kitchen wall, a real one-of-a-kind masterpiece. Unfortunately, Missy's mom shares neither your enthusiasm nor your love for the arts. You are sent home pronto, and the last you saw of Missy,
she was being put into solitary confinement and holding a pillow on her rear end.

A valiant choice with an unfortunate outcome. When Missy's mother discovers her masterpiece, she gives you joint credit. She does not know that you are definitely an impressionist while Missy is a cubist. Adults!
